title: Grade 6 Electricity and Electrical Devices Terms

questions.definition: A form of energy resulting from the movement of charged particles through a conductor.
A complete path that allows electric current to flow.
A material that allows electric current to flow easily through it, often metals.
A material that resists the flow of electric current, often used to protect wires.
The force that pushes electric charges through a circuit.
The flow of electric charge through a circuit, measured in amperes.
The opposition to the flow of electric current, which affects how much energy is lost as heat.
A device that stores chemical energy and converts it into electrical energy to power circuits.
A circuit where components are connected in a single path, so the same current flows through all parts.
A circuit where components are connected in multiple paths, allowing current to flow through more than one route.
A device that can open or close a circuit, controlling the flow of electricity.
A buildup of electric charge on the surface of an object, often caused by friction.
A temporary magnet created by passing electric current through a coil of wire wrapped around a core.
A safety device that breaks the circuit if the current becomes too high.
A device that converts mechanical energy into electrical energy.
A device that changes the voltage of an electric current, either increasing or decreasing it.
A principle stating that energy cannot be created or destroyed, only transformed from one form to another.
A device that stores electrical energy temporarily in a circuit.
A device that converts electrical energy into mechanical energy to create motion.
Energy that comes from sources that are naturally replenished, like sunlight or wind.
Energy that comes from sources that cannot be replenished, like fossil fuels.
The ability of a material to allow electric current to pass through it.
The process of using electric current to drive a chemical reaction.
A device that converts sunlight directly into electricity.
A fault in a circuit that allows current to flow along an unintended path, often causing overheating.
